trans-unit.source: Create a virtual network with a site-to-site VPN connection using Azure Resource Manager and PowerShell | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Create a virtual network with a site-to-site VPN connection using Azure Resource Manager and PowerShell | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Create a site-to-site VPN connection from your virtual network to your on-premises location by using Azure Resource Manager and PowerShell
trans-unit.target: Create a site-to-site VPN connection from your virtual network to your on-premises location by using Azure Resource Manager and PowerShell

trans-unit.source: This topic will walk you through creating an Azure Resource Manager virtual network and a site-to-site VPN connection to your on-premises network.
trans-unit.target: This topic will walk you through creating an Azure Resource Manager virtual network and a site-to-site VPN connection to your on-premises network.

trans-unit.source: Azure currently has two deployment models: the classic deployment model, and the Azure Resource Manager deployment model.
trans-unit.target: Azure currently has two deployment models: the classic deployment model, and the Azure Resource Manager deployment model.

trans-unit.source: The site-to-site setup is different, depending on the model that was used to deploy your virtual network.
trans-unit.target: The site-to-site setup is different, depending on the model that was used to deploy your virtual network.

trans-unit.source: These instructions apply to Resource Manager.
trans-unit.target: These instructions apply to Resource Manager.

trans-unit.source: If you want to create a site-to-site VPN gateway connection using the classic deployment model, see <linkText>Create a site-to-site VPN connection in the Management Portal</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: If you want to create a site-to-site VPN gateway connection using the classic deployment model, see <linkText>Create a site-to-site VPN connection in the Management Portal</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: Before you begin, verify that you have the following:
trans-unit.target: Before you begin, verify that you have the following:

trans-unit.source: A compatible VPN device (and someone who is able to configure it).
trans-unit.target: A compatible VPN device (and someone who is able to configure it).

trans-unit.source: See <linkText>About VPN Devices</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: See <linkText>About VPN Devices</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: An externally-facing public IP address for your VPN device.
trans-unit.target: An externally-facing public IP address for your VPN device.

trans-unit.source: This IP address cannot be located behind a NAT.
trans-unit.target: This IP address cannot be located behind a NAT.

trans-unit.source: The latest version of Azure PowerShell cmdlets.
trans-unit.target: The latest version of Azure PowerShell cmdlets.

trans-unit.source: You can download and install the latest version from the Windows PowerShell section of the <linkText>Download page</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: You can download and install the latest version from the Windows PowerShell section of the <linkText>Download page</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: An Azure subscription.
trans-unit.target: An Azure subscription.

trans-unit.source: If you don't already have an Azure subscription, you can activate your <linkText>MSDN subscriber benefits</linkText><title></title> or sign up for a <linkText>free trial</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: If you don't already have an Azure subscription, you can activate your <linkText>MSDN subscriber benefits</linkText><title></title> or sign up for a <linkText>free trial</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: Open your PowerShell console and switch to the Azure Resource Manager mode.
trans-unit.target: Open your PowerShell console and switch to the Azure Resource Manager mode.

trans-unit.source: Use the following sample to help you connect:
trans-unit.target: Use the following sample to help you connect:

trans-unit.source: Use the Select-AzureSubscription to connect to the subscription that you want to use.
trans-unit.target: Use the Select-AzureSubscription to connect to the subscription that you want to use.

trans-unit.source: Next, switch to the ARM mode.
trans-unit.target: Next, switch to the ARM mode.

trans-unit.source: This will switch the mode to allow you to use the ARM cmdlets.
trans-unit.target: This will switch the mode to allow you to use the ARM cmdlets.

trans-unit.source: If you already have a virtual network with a gateway subnet, you can go jump ahead to <linkText>Add your local site</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: If you already have a virtual network with a gateway subnet, you can go jump ahead to <linkText>Add your local site</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: If you have a virtual network and you want to add a gateway subnet to your VNet, see <linkText>Add a gateway subnet to a VNet</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: If you have a virtual network and you want to add a gateway subnet to your VNet, see <linkText>Add a gateway subnet to a VNet</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: Use the sample below to create a virtual network and a gateway subnet.
trans-unit.target: Use the sample below to create a virtual network and a gateway subnet.

trans-unit.source: Substitute the values for your own.
trans-unit.target: Substitute the values for your own.

trans-unit.source: First, create a Resource Group:
trans-unit.target: First, create a Resource Group:

trans-unit.source: Next, create your virtual network.
trans-unit.target: Next, create your virtual network.

trans-unit.source: The sample below creates a virtual network named testvnet and two subnets, one called GatewaySubnet and the other called Subnet1.
trans-unit.target: The sample below creates a virtual network named testvnet and two subnets, one called GatewaySubnet and the other called Subnet1.

trans-unit.source: It's important to create one subnet named specifically GatewaySubnet.
trans-unit.target: It's important to create one subnet named specifically GatewaySubnet.

trans-unit.source: If you name it something else, your connection configuration will fail.
trans-unit.target: If you name it something else, your connection configuration will fail.

trans-unit.source: If you already have an existing virtual network and you want to add a gateway subnet to it, you can create your gateway subnet by using the sample below.
trans-unit.target: If you already have an existing virtual network and you want to add a gateway subnet to it, you can create your gateway subnet by using the sample below.

trans-unit.source: Be sure to name the gateway subnet 'GatewaySubnet'.
trans-unit.target: Be sure to name the gateway subnet 'GatewaySubnet'.

trans-unit.source: If you name it something else, your VPN configuration will not work as expected.
trans-unit.target: If you name it something else, your VPN configuration will not work as expected.

trans-unit.source: In a virtual network, the local site typically refers to your on-premises location.
trans-unit.target: In a virtual network, the local site typically refers to your on-premises location.

trans-unit.source: You'll give that site a name by which Azure can refer to it.
trans-unit.target: You'll give that site a name by which Azure can refer to it.

trans-unit.source: You'll also specify the address space prefix for the local site.
trans-unit.target: You'll also specify the address space prefix for the local site.

trans-unit.source: Azure will use the IP address prefix you specify to identify which traffic to send to the local site.
trans-unit.target: Azure will use the IP address prefix you specify to identify which traffic to send to the local site.

trans-unit.source: This means that you'll have to specify each address prefix that you want to be associated with the local site.
trans-unit.target: This means that you'll have to specify each address prefix that you want to be associated with the local site.

trans-unit.source: You can easily update these prefixes if your on-premises network changes.
trans-unit.target: You can easily update these prefixes if your on-premises network changes.

trans-unit.source: Use the PowerShell samples below to specify your local site.
trans-unit.target: Use the PowerShell samples below to specify your local site.

trans-unit.source: The GatewayIPAddress is the IP address of your on-premises VPN device.
trans-unit.target: The GatewayIPAddress is the IP address of your on-premises VPN device.

trans-unit.source: Your VPN device cannot be located behind a NAT.
trans-unit.target: Your VPN device cannot be located behind a NAT.

trans-unit.source: The AddressPrefix is your on-premises address space.
trans-unit.target: The AddressPrefix is your on-premises address space.

trans-unit.source: Use this example to add a local site with a single address prefix.
trans-unit.target: Use this example to add a local site with a single address prefix.

trans-unit.source: If you want to add a local site with multiple address prefixes, use this example.
trans-unit.target: If you want to add a local site with multiple address prefixes, use this example.

trans-unit.source: To add additional address prefixes to a local site that you already created, use the example below.
trans-unit.target: To add additional address prefixes to a local site that you already created, use the example below.

trans-unit.source: To remove an address prefix from a local site, use the example below.
trans-unit.target: To remove an address prefix from a local site, use the example below.

trans-unit.source: Leave out the prefixes that you no longer need.
trans-unit.target: Leave out the prefixes that you no longer need.

trans-unit.source: In this example, we no longer need prefix 20.0.0.0/24 (from the previous example), so we will update the local site and exclude that prefix.
trans-unit.target: In this example, we no longer need prefix 20.0.0.0/24 (from the previous example), so we will update the local site and exclude that prefix.

trans-unit.source: Next, you'll request a public IP address to be allocated to your Azure VNet VPN gateway.
trans-unit.target: Next, you'll request a public IP address to be allocated to your Azure VNet VPN gateway.

trans-unit.source: This is not the same IP address that is assigned to your VPN device, rather it's assigned to the Azure VPN gateway itself.
trans-unit.target: This is not the same IP address that is assigned to your VPN device, rather it's assigned to the Azure VPN gateway itself.

trans-unit.source: You cannot specify the IP address that you want to use; it is dynamically allocated to your gateway.
trans-unit.target: You cannot specify the IP address that you want to use; it is dynamically allocated to your gateway.

trans-unit.source: You'll use this IP address when configuring your on-premises VPN device to connect to the gateway.
trans-unit.target: You'll use this IP address when configuring your on-premises VPN device to connect to the gateway.

trans-unit.source: Use the PowerShell sample below.
trans-unit.target: Use the PowerShell sample below.

trans-unit.source: The Allocation Method for this address must be Dynamic.
trans-unit.target: The Allocation Method for this address must be Dynamic.

trans-unit.source: The gateway configuration defines the subnet and the public IP address to use.
trans-unit.target: The gateway configuration defines the subnet and the public IP address to use.

trans-unit.source: Use the sample below to create your gateway configuration.
trans-unit.target: Use the sample below to create your gateway configuration.

trans-unit.source: In this step, you'll create the virtual network gateway.
trans-unit.target: In this step, you'll create the virtual network gateway.

trans-unit.source: Use the following values:
trans-unit.target: Use the following values:

trans-unit.source: The Gateway Type is Vpn.
trans-unit.target: The Gateway Type is Vpn.

trans-unit.source: The VpnType can be RouteBased* (referred to as a Dynamic Gateway in some documentation), or Policy Based (referred to as a Static Gateway in some documentation).
trans-unit.target: The VpnType can be RouteBased* (referred to as a Dynamic Gateway in some documentation), or Policy Based (referred to as a Static Gateway in some documentation).

trans-unit.source: For more information about VPN gateway types, see <linkText>About VPN Gateways</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For more information about VPN gateway types, see <linkText>About VPN Gateways</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: At this point, you'll need the public IP address of the virtual network gateway for configuring your on-premises VPN device.
trans-unit.target: At this point, you'll need the public IP address of the virtual network gateway for configuring your on-premises VPN device.

trans-unit.source: Work with your device manufacturer for specific configuration information.
trans-unit.target: Work with your device manufacturer for specific configuration information.

trans-unit.source: Additionally, refer to the <linkText>VPN Devices</linkText><title></title> for more information.
trans-unit.target: Additionally, refer to the <linkText>VPN Devices</linkText><title></title> for more information.

trans-unit.source: To find the public IP address of your virtual network gateway, use the following sample:
trans-unit.target: To find the public IP address of your virtual network gateway, use the following sample:

trans-unit.source: Next, you'll create the site-to-site VPN connection between your virtual network gateway and your VPN device.
trans-unit.target: Next, you'll create the site-to-site VPN connection between your virtual network gateway and your VPN device.

trans-unit.source: Be sure to replace the values for your own.
trans-unit.target: Be sure to replace the values for your own.

trans-unit.source: The shared key must match the value you used for your VPN device configuration.
trans-unit.target: The shared key must match the value you used for your VPN device configuration.

trans-unit.source: After a few minutes, the connection should be established.
trans-unit.target: After a few minutes, the connection should be established.

trans-unit.source: At this time, the site-to-site VPN connections created with Resource Manager are not visible in the Portal.
trans-unit.target: At this time, the site-to-site VPN connections created with Resource Manager are not visible in the Portal.

trans-unit.source: Add a virtual machine to your virtual network.
trans-unit.target: Add a virtual machine to your virtual network.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Create a Virtual Machine</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Create a Virtual Machine</linkText><title></title>.
